text.sentence: This report has been updated to correct our oil price assumption on page two.
We think COP's fourQfifteen announcement will have a negative impact on the shares' near term performance.
However, after the dust has settled over the next couple weeks, we expect the shares will begin to recover and outperform other E and P names.
In light of management's decision to cut their dividend to dollar .twenty

five/share per quarter, we believe COP has repositioned itself to become one of the lowest breakeven cost producers in the E and P sector and it has also become one of the lowest balance sheet risk companies in the group.
Please refer to our recent report, Will COP Cut the Dividend?, dated January twenty five, two thousand sixteen for a more detailed analysis.

Concurrent to the dividend cut, COP announced a reduction in its capex budget to dollar six.four billion from dollar seven.seven billion prior, made possible in part by a reduction in drilling activity in the Lower forty eight.
We estimate COP's cash burn will be a very manageable dollar three billion annually in two thousand sixteen and two thousand seventeen under a dollar thirty five oil price environment.
We think the dividend cut drastically improves its operational and financial flexibility.

We estimate the company will now be cash flow breakeven after dividend and sustaining capex at < dollar fifty oil, consistent with management's indication that its new breakeven oil price is around dollar forty five.
Thus, COP has become one of the sector's lowest breakeven cost producers.
They could grow production at two four percent p.a. and increase the dividend by four six percent accordingly under a dollar sixty oil environment.
We believe the new value proposition is modest production growth and strong cash return over the cycle.

However, instead of dividends, the cash return would include a steadily rising dividend payout and also a new lever, the share buyback, which allows the company to be more flexible throughout the various commodity price cycles.

As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report.
Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

After having reduced its dividend by sixty six percent, we believe COP has repositioned itself to become one of the lowest breakeven cost producers in the sector, and one of the lowest balance sheet risk companies in the group.
Its cash burn over twenty million one hundred sixty two thousand seventeen could now be at a much more manageable level, even at dollar thirty five oil.
Our price target is based on our NAV at dollar sixty five oil.
Our upside case assumes a long term Brent price deck of dollar ninety/bl in our NAV analysis.
Our downside scenario assumes a long term oil price deck of dollar fifty/bl in our NAV analysis.

Since the false signs of a price recovery exhibited in oneHfifteen, the global oil market has resumed a relentless downward spiral, pushing below dollar thirty/bl Brent for the first time in over twelve years.

Due in part to recent escalating political tensions between Saudi Arabia and Iran, in anticipation of the latter's re entry as a global exporter, we would characterize sentiment as validly cautious yet exaggerated.

That being said, we do not expect to see an inflection toward an improving supply demand balance until twoHsixteen, with sufficient data to support a sustained price recovery until late two thousand sixteen / early two thousand seventeen.

Although we are encouraged by the recent discussion between Saudi Arabia and Russia for a cooperative oil production cut to rebalance the market, we think it is premature to assume the discussion will definitively lead to immediate action.
Absent a shift of Saudi Arabia oil policy, we expect the global oil market will need until the end of this year or early two thousand seventeen before the underlying fundamentals begin to improve.
In two thousand fifteen, we estimate the market was oversupplied by .eight
The group now reflects a long term oil price deck of dollar fifty five dollar sixty Brent or dollar fifty dollar fifty five WTI, in our view.

While we continue to think the global oil market will likely average dollar eighty dollar ninety per barrel by two thousand eighteen, we assume the market will unlikely be willing to value the sector at more than dollar fifty five dollar sixty five Brent over the next twelve months, given the current futures strip averaging only dollar thirty six.two and dollar forty one.eight
for Brent in two thousand sixteen and two thousand seventeen and dollar thirty five.seven and dollar forty one.five
We expect Brent to be range bound over the next several quarters.
That being said, we think the sector's valuation will improve sharply over the next three years as global oil demand and supply returns to a tighter balance.

Oil prices in two thousand sixteen are likely to resemble continued noise, volatility, and sticky downward pressure, especially for the first nine months, in our opinion as market participants assess the key competing impacts of:
mmb/d, as per the prevailing bearish stance, or maintain a healthier global growth rate around one.two one.four

We expect two thousand sixteen Brent prices to range between mid dollar twenty/bl and dollar fifty/bl the upper range dependent on whether supply/demand tightening is visible by early fourQsixteen or closer to two thousand seventeen.
We see the Brent/WTI differential ranging from dollar dollar three, reflecting a gradual spread increase over twoHsixteen from the current flat / moderately slightly inverted level.
The steep contango curve has resulted in the temporary breakdown of the normal relationship between crude differentials and transportation costs.
Currently, financial buyers could theoretically earn a risk free arbitrage by storing oil at Cushing and shorting futures, at least until the curve flattens, or we run out of storage space .
More recently, pressure on the differential has caused it to invert, with WTI at an average dollar one.four/bl
As outlined in the figure below, over the next three years we expect global oil supplies could potentially add two.six four.one million b/d from: Iran, the Neutral Zone, Libya, NGLs, and Biofuels .
On the other hand, we expect US production could decline .three
mmb/d next year while the OPEC countries may decline by .one
In addition, we think non US, non OPEC production could drop thirteen percent, or .three
mmb/d by two thousand eighteen as major project sanctions have slowed to a near halt since late two thousand thirteen.
As a result, we estimate total available supplies in excess of two thousand fifteen demand at one.three.thirty
five mmb/d over the next three years compared to our base case estimate of potential demand growth of roughly three.six
This implies U.S. production may need to increase by an average of up to one.
Additionally, while we don't doubt the ability of U.S. production to grow by one.
In our opinion, this is not a question of well economics, but one of liquidity.
At what price will domestic producers generate sufficient cash flow to fund drilling activities enough to increase output by one.
Our best guess is that WTI prices will need to average at least dollar seventy dollar eighty/bl, which implies Brent exceeding dollar seventy five dollar eighty five/bl by two thousand eighteen.

That said, if demand growth falls into our low case scenario, the global oil market probably will not begin to recover until late two thousand seventeen/early two thousand eighteen if there is no change to Saudi oil policy.
FIGURE one Global Oil Supply and Demand Balance, two thousand fifteen two thousand eighteen

Supply: Potential Major Sources of Increase Iran Neutral Zone Libya NGL Biofuel Total Supply: Potential Major Sources of Decrease US two thousand sixteen Decline Rest of OPEC members NonUS and NonOPEC Total Net Supply Increase Demand: Estimate Demand Growth Net Increase Est.
Positive risk factors to oil prices: · We expect global oil demand will continue to exceed expectations.
Despite a fasterthan expected growth deceleration in China in fourQfifteen, we see a relatively mitigated net effect on global demand growth.

Our base case does not assume a Chinese economic implosion given the fact that policymakers still have at their disposal ample firepower to address potential economic crises, such as stock market crashes or housing bubbles.

While the long term risks to the Chinese economy would only grow from such kicking the can down the road, the short to medium term interests of policymakers should probably ensure any necessary stabilizing actions will be taken.
Thus, we see a low probability of a China Hard Landing to the global oil market, at least for now.
mmb/d in two thousand fifteen and estimate the annual growth rate will drop to one.two
one.four million b/d per annum between two thousand sixteen and two thousand eighteen.
equipment team, we expect global E and P spending to decline by fifteen percent twenty percent in two thousand sixteen, and budgets in North
Barclays | ConocoPhillips America alone to decline by twenty seven percent in two thousand sixteen.

We estimate our group of U.S. majors, specifically, is cutting total spending by over twenty one percent in aggregate in two thousand sixteen ­ a twenty five percent spending reduction in N.A. and a twenty percent spending reduction outside of N.A. Actual spending cuts will likely exceed our estimates, since most budgets have been set based on dollar fortys/bl oil.

Additionally, while the market's focus has rightfully been on the resilience of U.S. oil production in the face of continued capex and rig cuts, we believe U.S. oil production should remain in a sequential downtrend in the coming quarters.
Furthermore, we think that by two thousand sixteen we could potentially see the first signs of a production drop in non OPEC, non U.S. oil producers.
especially as both countries have called for an emergency OPEC meeting.
Meanwhile, we see Iraqi production as remaining flat to slightly down under the current oil price environment, relative to the record two thousand fifteen level > four.
The Iraqi government has called on international oil companies to cut budgets and hold production steady.
We also think that Angola production could begin to trend lower reflecting the lack of new major projects being sanctioned since late two thousand thirteen.

Lastly, we think Russian production may be flat in two thousand sixteen due to the ongoing effects of sanctions, potential for additional large cuts to a budget originally planned around dollar fifty/bl, the delay of the planned cut in oil export duties, and the potential new oil tax plan that would increase mineral taxes.
Negative risk factors to oil prices: · We expect Iran will ramp up production faster and higher than the market's current
However, we do not believe the country could push much beyond that level over the next two three years.
Iran has repeatedly failed to achieve its target of reaching > five.
There has been news that suggests that the jointly operated fields between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia will resume operations and exports soon.
Militant factions need foreign currency and oil would be the only avenue for them.
We expect Libya to settle into an unstable equilibrium where different factions will control different parts of the country and avoid large scale all out wars.
We think it is important to note that the potential production uplift from the Neutral Zone and Libya collectively is bigger than the potential uplift from Iran.
We expect imports to remain elevated due to rising floating storage costs and the steep contango curve in the NYMEX market.
We expect this trend will lead to a build up of crude inventories in PADDs two and three collectively by an average of four five million barrels per week, between now and the end of April.

While we don't believe the U.S. will actually run out of crude storage, we expect the inventory build will eventually put downward pressure on U.S. crude prices over the next several months, particularly LLS versus Brent.

Crude differentials to remain a tailwind for US coastal refiners but a headwind for inland refiners We think the Gulf Coast and East Coast complex refiners will continue to be amongst the greatest beneficiaries in the industry from the current state of global oversupply in the crude oil market.

In addition to the current OPEC policy of defending market share, light/heavy and light/medium discounts will also widen due to continuing rising Canadian bitumen production and the ramping up of deepwater projects in the GOM.
Barclays | ConocoPhillips spread increased from dollar seven.three/b, or fourteen percent of LLS, to dollar nine.two/b, or twenty one percent of LLS.
And the two thousand sixteen YTD trend has widened further to an almost thirty percent discount.

Even if it does not stay at this very high level, the development is a tremendously beneficial margin uplift to those with the coking ability and geographic access to run the discounted heavy crude imports.
Going forward, we do not expect OPEC policy to abate at least this year.
We estimate WTI Cushing/WCS averages dollar fifteen.seven/b in two thousand sixteen, or forty six percent of WTI Cushing vs. the two thousand fifteen average of dollar thirteen.one/b,
Meanwhile, we estimate LLS/Maya will average dollar eight.two/b, or twenty four percent of LLS, vs. the two thousand fifteen average of dollar eight.three/b, or sixteen percent of LLS.
Furthering the glut is the US Gulf Coast as perhaps the only readily available and large destination for surplus barrels.
Due to the oversupply, practically all other onshore storage capacity in the Atlantic basin has been maxed out.

To avoid selling at the spot price into an oversupplied market, the typical West African producer looking to clear its barrels can either turn to floating storage and pay the monthly storage rate of roughly dollar one.three
dollar one.five/b, or it can send its barrels to the US Gulf Coast for onshore storage at a transportation cost of roughly dollar one.five
dollar two.five/b and a monthly storage cost of dollar .three
On the surface, the arbitrage window does not open unless LLS trades at a premium of several dollars vs. Brent.

But the swing factor here is the US contango curve, which we estimate at roughly dollar one/b per month over the next several three months, providing an immediate incremental uplift to anyone storing barrels in the US; ie, the only marginal buyers on the market with the financial incentive to take on additional crude into storage are the US based PADD two + three buyers.

Therefore, even though we assume Brent LLS remains at dollar one/b for the first half of two thousand sixteen, we think Gulf Coast imports will maintain their recent high level even as the refiners reach the peak of their spring turnaround season in the coming weeks.
Meanwhile, the slowing US production profile means that widening coastal differentials won't necessarily be mirrored inland.

When combined with the strength in imports and incentive for traders to store barrels in Cushing, we think the normal relationship between transportation cost and differentials will be temporarily broken.
We assume that WTI Cushing trades on par with Brent in oneHsixteen before gradually slipping into a discount in twoHsixteen, and reaching a dollar three discount in fourQsixteen.

We think COP's fourQfifteen announcement will have a negative impact on the shares' near term performance.
However, after the dust has settled over the next couple weeks, we expect the shares will begin to recover and outperform other E and P names.
In light of management's decision to cut their dividend to dollar .twenty

five/share per quarter, we believe COP has repositioned itself to become one of the lowest breakeven cost producers in the E and P sector and it has also become one of the lowest balance sheet risk companies in the group.
Please refer to our recent report, Will COP Cut the Dividend?, dated January twenty fiveth, two thousand sixteen for a more detailed analysis.
As a result, we think COP will become one of the anchor companies in most investors' E and P portfolios for the remainder of this down cycle.

Concurrent to the dividend cut, COP also announced a reduction in their capex budget to dollar six.four billion from dollar seven.seven billion prior, made possible in part by a reduction in drilling activity in the Lower forty eight.
At the same time, total production is expected flat compared with two thousand fifteen at one thousand five hundred twenty five mboe/d after taking into account asset sales.

With the changes, we estimate COP's cash burn will be a very manageable level of dollar three billion annually in two thousand sixteen and two thousand seventeen under a dollar thirty five oil price environment.
We think the dividend cut drastically improves their operational and financial flexibility.

We estimate the company will now be cash flow breakeven after dividend and sustaining capex at < dollar fifty oil, consistent with management's indication that its new breakeven oil price is around dollar forty five.
Thus, COP has become one of the sector's lowest breakeven cost producers.
They could grow production at two four percent p.a. and increase dividend by four six percent accordingly under a dollar sixty oil environment.
We believe the new value proposition is modest production growth and strong cash return over the cycle.

However, instead of dividend, the cash return will include a steadily rising dividend payout and also a new lever, the share buyback, which allows the company to be more flexible throughout the various commodity price cycles.
Why was the stock down nine percent on the day of the announcement?

While we have found through conversations with clients that many investors share our view that COP is better off cutting the dividend, we acknowledge that some of COP's investor base are dividend investors that may have been forced to sell once the announcement was made.

The remainder of the underperformance is likely due, in our opinion, to retail investors who may have been spooked by the news and hedge funds capitalizing on the negative sentiment to short the stock.

We fully expected such an initial reaction, and again, we think that once the dust has settled the new value proposition that COP offers will emerge in the forefront of the sector for many E and P investors.
Critically, we think that by biting the bullet now instead of waiting, COP has done so while it still has a choice, and thus greater financial flexibility to carry it out.

Should the company have foregone the current opportunity, and should the oil market remain depressed, it could have been forced into cutting the dividend at a point where it had zero optionality and the long term damage to the company would have been more severe.

Taking into account the updated two thousand sixteen guidance, we revise our FYsixteen EPS estimate to a loss of dollar two.eighty five/share compared to our previous estimate of a dollar three.five/share

We think COP's fourQfifteen announcement will have a negative impact on the shares' near term performance.
However, after the dust has settled over the next couple weeks, we expect the shares will begin to recover and outperform other E and P names.
In light of management's decision to cut their dividend to dollar .twenty

As a result, we think COP will become one of the anchor companies in most investors' E and P portfolios for the remainder of this down cycle.

Cheng, CFA, hereby certify that the views expressed in this research report accurately reflect my personal views about any or all of the subject securities or issuers referred to in this research report and no part of my compensation was, is or will be directly or indirectly related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this research report.
Barclays Research is a part of the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC and its affiliates .

Where any companies are the subject of this research report, for current important disclosures regarding those companies please send a written request to: Barclays Research Compliance, seven hundred forty five Seventh Avenue, thirteenth Floor, New York, NY ten thousand nineteen or refer to http://publicresearch.barclays
dot com or call two hundred twelve five hundred twenty six one thousand seventy two.

The analysts responsible for preparing this research report have received compensation based upon various factors including the firm's total revenues, a portion of which is generated by investment banking activities.

Analysts regularly conduct site visits to view the material operations of covered companies, but Barclays policy prohibits them from accepting payment or reimbursement by any covered company of their travel expenses for such visits.
In order to access Barclays Statement regarding Research Dissemination Policies and Procedures, please refer to http://publicresearch.barcap
In order to access Barclays Research Conflict Management Policy Statement, please refer to: http://publicresearch.barcap
The Investment Bank's Research Department produces various types of research including, but not limited to, fundamental analysis, equitylinked analysis, quantitative analysis, and trade ideas.

Recommendations contained in one type of research product may differ from recommendations contained in other types of research, whether as a result of differing time horizons, methodologies, or otherwise.

CE: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate is a market maker in equity securities issued by this issuer.
D: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate has received compensation for investment banking services from this issuer in the past twelve months.
E: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate expects to receive or intends to seek compensation for investment banking services from this issuer within the next three months.
F: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate beneficially owned one percent or more of a class of equity securities of the issuer as of the end of the month prior to the research report's issuance.
GD: One of the analysts on the fundamental credit coverage team has a financial interest in the debt or equity securities of this issuer.
GE: One of the analysts on the fundamental equity coverage team has a financial interest in the debt or equity securities of this issuer.
H: This issuer beneficially owns five percent or more of any class of common equity securities of Barclays PLC.
I: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate has a significant financial interest in the securities of this issuer.
J: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate is a liquidity provider and/or trades regularly in the securities of this issuer and/or in any related derivatives.
K: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate has received non investment banking related compensation from this issuer within the past twelve months.
L: This issuer is, or during the past twelve months has been, an investment banking client of Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate.
M: This issuer is, or during the past twelve months has been, a non investment banking client of Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate.
N: This issuer is, or during the past twelve months has been, a non investment banking client of Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate.
O: Barclays Capital Inc., through Barclays Market Makers, is a Designated Market Maker in this issuer's stock, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
At any given time, its associated Designated Market Maker may have long or short inventory position in the stock; and its five February two thousand sixteen twenty three
associated Designated Market Maker may be on the opposite side of orders executed on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in the stock.

P: A partner, director or officer of Barclays Capital Canada Inc. has, during the preceding twelve months, provided services to the subject company for remuneration, other than normal course investment advisory or trade execution services.
Q: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate is a Corporate Broker to this issuer.
R: Barclays Capital Canada Inc. and/or an affiliate has received compensation for investment banking services from this issuer in the past twelve months.
S: Barclays Capital Canada Inc. is a market maker in an equity or equity related security issued by this issuer.
T: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate is providing equity advisory services to this issuer.
U: The equity securities of this Canadian issuer include subordinate voting restricted shares.
V: The equity securities of this Canadian issuer include non voting restricted shares.

W: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate should be assumed to be an actual beneficial owner of one percent or more of all the securities of this issuer as of the end of the month prior to the research report's issuance.
Risk Disclosure Master limited partnerships are pass through entities structured as publicly listed partnerships.
For tax purposes, distributions to MLP unit holders may be treated as a return of principal.
Investors should consult their own tax advisors before investing in MLP units.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Below is the list of companies that constitute the industry coverage universe: Americas Integrated Oil Cenovus Energy Inc.
Exxon Mobil Corp. Imperial Oil Ltd. Petroleo Brasileiro S.A. Distribution of Ratings: Barclays Equity Research has one thousand eight hundred eighty six companies under coverage.

forty one percent have been assigned an Overweight rating which, for purposes of mandatory regulatory disclosures, is classified as a Buy rating; sixty one percent of companies with this rating are investment banking clients of the Firm.

forty percent have been assigned an Equal Weight rating which, for purposes of mandatory regulatory disclosures, is classified as a Hold rating; fifty percent of companies with this rating are investment banking clients of the Firm.

fifteen percent have been assigned an Underweight rating which, for purposes of mandatory regulatory disclosures, is classified as a Sell rating; forty three percent of companies with this rating are investment banking clients of the Firm.

Guide to the Barclays Research Price Target: five February two thousand sixteen twenty four Chevron Corporation Hess Corp. Murphy Oil Suncor Energy ConocoPhillips Husky Energy, Inc. Petroleo Brasileiro S.A.
Each analyst has a single price target on the stocks that they cover.
The price target represents that analyst's expectation of where the stock will trade in the next twelve months.
Upside/downside scenarios, where provided, represent potential upside/potential downside to each analyst's price target over the same twelve month period.
Top Picks: Barclays Equity Research's Top Picks represent the single best alpha generating investment idea within each industry, taken from among the Overweight rated stocks within that industry.
Barclays Equity Research publishes global and regional Top Picks reports every quarter and analysts may also publish intra quarter changes to their Top Picks, as necessary.
While analysts may highlight other Overweight rated stocks in their published research in addition to their Top Pick, there can only be one Top Pick for each industry.
To view the current list of Top Picks, go to the Top Picks page on Barclays Live .
To see a list of companies that comprise a particular industry coverage universe, please go to http://publicresearch.barclays

A: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate has been lead manager or co lead manager of a publicly disclosed offer of securities of Chevron Corporation in the previous twelve months.
CD: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate is a market maker in debt securities issued by Chevron Corporation.
CE: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate is a market maker in equity securities issued by Chevron Corporation.
D: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate has received compensation for investment banking services from Chevron Corporation in the past twelve months.
E: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate expects to receive or intends to seek compensation for investment banking services from Chevron Corporation within the next three months.
J: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate is a liquidity provider and/or trades regularly in the securities by Chevron Corporation and/or in any related derivatives.
K: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate has received non investment banking related compensation from Chevron Corporation within the past twelve months.
L: Chevron Corporation is, or during the past twelve months has been, an investment banking client of Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate.
M: Chevron Corporation is, or during the past twelve months has been, a non investment banking client of Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate.
N: Chevron Corporation is, or during the past twelve months has been, a non investment banking client of Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate.
O: Barclays Capital Inc., through Barclays Market Makers, is a Designated Market Maker in Chevron Corporation stock, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

At any given time, its associated Designated Market Maker may have long or short inventory position in the stock; and its associated Designated Market Maker may be on the opposite side of orders executed on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in the stock.
Valuation Methodology: Using our net asset valuation framework, we assume a long term Brent and WTI price of dollar sixty five/bl and dollar fifty nine/bl, respectively.
In addition, we assign slightly higher premiums for chemicals and refiners when the company has historically shown higher returns compared to peers.
We also take into account our estimate of expected free cash flow and EV/after tax cash flow analysis in our assessment.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Our earnings estimates are based on Barclays Research's current commodity price assumptions, including oil and gas prices, refining and marketing margins as well as chemical product margins.
Thus, results will be subject to change due to fluctuations in the macro commodity market environment.

D: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate has received compensation for investment banking services from Exxon Mobil Corp. in the past twelve months.

K: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate has received non investment banking related compensation from Exxon Mobil Corp. within the past twelve months.
L: Exxon Mobil Corp. is, or during the past twelve months has been, an investment banking client of Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate.

O: Barclays Capital Inc., through Barclays Market Makers, is a Designated Market Maker in Exxon Mobil Corp. stock, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

At any given time, its associated Designated Market Maker may have long or short inventory position in the stock; and its associated Designated Market Maker may be on the opposite side of orders executed on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in the stock.
Valuation Methodology: Using our net asset valuation framework, we assume a long term Brent and WTI price of dollar sixty five/bl and dollar fifty nine/bl, respectively.
In addition, we assign slightly higher premiums for chemicals and refiners when the company has historically shown higher returns compared to peers.
We also take into account our estimate of expected free cash flow and EV/after tax cash flow analysis in our assessment.
Finally, for XOM we assume a twenty percent premium to our NAV estimate.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Our earnings estimates are based on Barclays Research's current commodity price assumptions, including oil and gas prices, refining and marketing margins as well as chemical product margins.
Thus, results will be subject to change due to fluctuations in the macro commodity market environment.
